1.text:
Hubble's Wide Field Camera 3 has captured
this image of a giant cloud of hydrogen gas

7.text:
illuminated by a bright young star. The image
shows how violent the end stages of the star

13.text:
formation process can be, with the young object
shaking up its stellar nursery.

20.text:
A few thousand light-years away, in the constellation
of Cygnus, lies the compact star-forming region

28.text:
Sh 2-106, or S106 for short. Despite the celestial
colors of this picture, there is nothing peaceful

42.text:
about this scene. A young star, named S106
IR, is being born at the heart of the nebula.

50.text:
In the violent final stages of its formation,
the star is ejecting material at high speed,

57.text:
violently disrupting the gas and dust. 3D
visualizations show the extent to which the

63.text:
star has carved its surroundings into a complex
shape. In particular, the hourglass-like structure

69.text:
of the nebula is a result of jets from the
star slamming into the cloud of hydrogen it

77.text:
At the outer edges of these cavities, the
gas has been compressed into shock fronts

81.text:
by the pressure. The star has a mass about
15 times that of the Sun and is in the final

93.text:
stages of its formation. It will soon quiet
down by entering the adult stage of stellar

99.text: life, known to astronomers as the main sequence.

102.text:
For now, though, S106 IR remains embedded
in its parent cloud, but it is rebelling against

111.text:
it. The material spewing off the star not
only gives the cloud its hourglass shape but

118.text:
also makes the hydrogen gas turbulent. The
resulting intricate patterns are clearly visible

129.text:
As well as churning up the gas cloud, the
young star is also heating it up to temperatures

135.text:
of 10 000 degrees Celsius. The star's radiation
excites the gas, making it glow like a fluorescent

144.text:
bulb. The light from this glowing gas is colored
blue in this image, which combines Hubble

150.text:
observations taken in visible and infrared
light.

157.text:
Separating these regions of glowing gas is
a cooler, thick stream of dust, shown here

163.text:
in red. This dark material almost completely
hides the star from view, but the young object

170.text:
can still be seen faintly peeking through
the widest part of the dust lane.

177.text:
The cloud itself is relatively small by the
standards of star- forming regions, around

182.text:
two light-years in size along its longest
axis. This is about half the distance between

187.text:
the Sun and Proxima Centauri, our nearest
stellar neighbor, making it far smaller than

193.text:
familiar star-forming regions like the Orion
Nebula and Carina Nebula.
